awd_titl_txt: STTR Phase I:  Automated Continuous Varroa Mite Monitor for Honeybee Hive Health
awd_abstract_narration:
This Small Business Technology Transfer Phase I project addresses the health of honeybee hives and the associated $15 billion in annual agricultural services. Honeybee hives are susceptible to the parasitic Varroa destructor mite; unless the hive is treated, the presence of the Varroa mite eventually proves fatal to any bee colony it infests. Monitoring mite levels in beehives requires partial disassembly of the hive and the best counting method sacrifices some bees. Most of the nation’s 120,000+ beekeepers do not adequately test for mites. The expected output of this project is a low-cost, battery-operated “Internet-of-Things” device that can be placed inside hives, passively counting the Varroa mite population, and reporting the results to the beekeeper. The count can be used to indicate when mite treatment is needed and whether the treatment was effective. It prevents costly and unneeded prophylactic treatments that can lead to resistance in mite populations. This project fosters bee colonies that are healthy and productive, while reducing beekeeper workload and reducing unnecessary chemical treatments for beehives. 

The intellectual merit of this project is in the novel investigation of the use of near-infrared light wavelengths to determine where acceptable contrast exists between the exoskeletons of honeybees and Varroa mites, and the recognition of parasitic Varroa mites using modern artificial intelligence techniques that can be scaled to down for use in an edge computing environment that has significant limitations in terms of power availability and processing speed. The Phase I effort will integrate an infrared camera with variable wavelength narrowband infrared LED illumination, and photograph unparasitized and mite-infested honeybees. Human researchers will identify mites and use scored images to train an artificial intelligence engine to detect and count the mites.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
At BroodMinder, we've embarked on a transformative project to revolutionize beekeeping. Our groundbreaking technologies are specifically designed to combat the Varroa destructor mite, a parasitic intruder that has, since its North American arrival in the 1980s, escalated annual hive losses from 10% to a staggering 30-50%.

This issue is especially significant for hobby beekeepers, who often view their bees more as pets than livestock. For these individuals, the most common mite-counting method, which necessitates euthanizing some bees, is understandably unappealing. Recognizing this, our solution focuses on minimally-invasive, yet effective mite detection and management, ensuring the beekeepers can effectively combat Varroa infestations without causing harm to their beloved bees.

Our primary innovation is an in-hive camera system, powered by advanced deep learning algorithms. This system not only counts bees but also detects and tracks Varroa mites. By alerting beekeepers of any impending problems in a timely manner, our technology empowers them to intervene and protect their hives. The resulting stabilization of bee populations has profound implications for our ecosystem, as bees play an essential role in maintaining biodiversity and facilitating crop pollination, thereby significantly contributing to global food security.

In our pursuit of aiding hobby beekeepers, we've realized the broader impacts of healthier hives. Hobby beekeepers often engage with local communities, schools, and farmers markets. Their healthier hives can contribute to local pollination, boost biodiversity, support small-scale, diversified farming operations, and perhaps inspire others to take up beekeeping. While our first-generation technology may not initially reach large-scale commercial beekeepers, we anticipate that as our innovations evolve, they may pave the way for a viable solution for these beekeepers, potentially transforming commercial beekeeping practices on a broader scale in the future.

Our project's innovations, firmly grounded in the fields of deep learning and engineering, are poised to reverberate beyond these scientific domains. They promise significant contributions to ecological conservation, food security, local economies, and environmental education, marking a tangible difference in our world. The ripple effect of our work, we believe, will extend from the hives to our everyday lives, fostering a more ecologically conscious society.
